content.title: BGP Route Reflector Configuration - Scenario 1
content.config:
router bgp 65001
 router-id 10.1.1.1
 neighbor 10.1.1.2 remote-as 65001
 neighbor 10.1.1.2 route-reflector-client
 neighbor 10.1.1.3 remote-as 65001
 neighbor 10.1.1.3 route-reflector-client
 address-family ipv4 unicast
  neighbor 10.1.1.2 activate
  neighbor 10.1.1.3 activate
  neighbor 10.1.1.2 next-hop-self
  neighbor 10.1.1.3 next-hop-self
content.explanation: Route reflector reduces iBGP mesh complexity in large networks
content.use_case: Enterprise WAN with multiple ISP connections

 neighbor 10.1.1.3 route-reflector-client

  neighbor 10.1.1.2 activate
  neighbor 10.1.1.3 activate
  neighbor 10.1.1.2 next-hop-self
  neighbor 10.1.1.3 next-hop-self
content.explanation: Next-hop-self ensures reachability in iBGP environments
content.use_case: Enterprise WAN with multiple ISP connections

content.title: OSPF Multi-Area Configuration - Scenario 1
content.config:
router ospf 1
 router-id 10.1.1.1
 area 0 authentication message-digest
 area 1 stub
 network 10.1.1.0 0.0.0.255 area 0
 network 10.2.1.0 0.0.0.255 area 1
 passive-interface default
 no passive-interface GigabitEthernet0/0
content.explanation: Multi-area design reduces LSA flooding and SPF calculations
content.use_case: Large campus network with multiple buildings

content.title: OSPF Multi-Area Configuration - Scenario 2
content.config:
router ospf 1
 router-id 10.1.1.1
 area 0 authentication message-digest
 area 1 stub
 network 10.1.1.0 0.0.0.255 area 0
 network 10.2.1.0 0.0.0.255 area 1
 passive-interface default
 no passive-interface GigabitEthernet0/0
content.explanation: Stub areas block external LSAs reducing routing table size
content.use_case: Large campus network with multiple buildings

content.title: OSPF Multi-Area Configuration - Scenario 3
content.config:
router ospf 1
 router-id 10.1.1.1
 area 0 authentication message-digest
 area 1 stub
 network 10.1.1.0 0.0.0.255 area 0
 network 10.2.1.0 0.0.0.255 area 1
 passive-interface default
 no passive-interface GigabitEthernet0/0
content.explanation: Passive interfaces prevent unnecessary OSPF hellos
content.use_case: Large campus network with multiple buildings

content.title: QoS Policy Configuration - Scenario 1
content.config:
class-map match-all VOICE
 match dscp ef
class-map match-all VIDEO
 match dscp af41
policy-map WAN_QOS
 class VOICE
  priority percent 30
 class VIDEO
  bandwidth percent 40
 class class-default
  bandwidth percent 30
  random-detect
content.explanation: Priority queue guarantees delay-sensitive traffic like voice
content.use_case: Branch office with limited WAN bandwidth

content.title: QoS Policy Configuration - Scenario 2
content.config:
class-map match-all VOICE
 match dscp ef
class-map match-all VIDEO
 match dscp af41
policy-map WAN_QOS
 class VOICE
  priority percent 30
 class VIDEO
  bandwidth percent 40
 class class-default
  bandwidth percent 30
  random-detect
content.explanation: DSCP marking provides end-to-end QoS classification
content.use_case: Branch office with limited WAN bandwidth

content.title: QoS Policy Configuration - Scenario 3
content.config:
class-map match-all VOICE
 match dscp ef
class-map match-all VIDEO
 match dscp af41
policy-map WAN_QOS
 class VOICE
  priority percent 30
 class VIDEO
  bandwidth percent 40
 class class-default
  bandwidth percent 30
  random-detect
content.explanation: Random early detection prevents TCP global synchronization
content.use_case: Branch office with limited WAN bandwidth
